pros: Great work perks vacation, holidays, and a retirement matching program. Tuition benefits for employees with children at Lipscomb Academy and Lipscomb University. Working with college students keeps you thinking young and sharpens your skills! Christian co-workers make for a fantastic working environment.
cons: Compensation lags behind corporate. Advancement opportunities are fewer and many require advanced degrees---even for staff roles. No paid maternity leave for staff.

review_title: Great student job for IT majors
job_title: IT Helpdesk Support in Nashville, TN
pros:
Quiet & laidback work environment, located under the library on the bottom floor near the security office. Manager(s) were good at scheduling with students, allowing shifts when desired and not overlapping with classes or other duties. During slower hours (or after having answered/solved all recent tickets/calls/walk-ups ) you can periodically have time to study or work on homework, etc. 
 Being an IT Helpdesk support student worker as well as an IT Major comes with its own additional perks of course - establishing or strengthening connections with staff, employees and/or fellow students within the IT Department at Lipscomb, as well as gaining IT-related experience on the job.
Solid communication between management & workers via group messaging apps. Strengthened comfortability for handling IT helpdesk/IT support-related interactions and issues. Receiving access to keys & driving the Lipscomb-owned golf carts across campus to drop off or pick up IT Dept. mail can be fun. 
Free coffee (& sometimes snacks) from the break room during shifts.
cons:
Being the first barrier of IT Support-related contact amongst all students, alumni & staff at Lipscomb University for any & all tech related issues. 
Having to act as "messenger" to convey or explain one of a whole new cornucopia of issues with Lipscomb's shoddily-integrated new online system implemented a couple years ago (that is seriously still broken even today).
Rather low rates of pay for student workers, and even dismal rates for some full-time positions within the IT Department here at Lipscomb University especially. An alumnus buddy of mine who was a fellow Lipscomb student and helpdesk worker was hired to one of these higher full-time positions in the IT Dept. But despite being a recent Lipscomb graduate or years spent working in the IT dept as a student, he only makes around a mere $15 an hour. At that rate I doubt he'll even be able to afford nearby housing there around Green Hills. 

Weekly scheduling of helpdesk workers' hours could be less monopolized by a certain select few that seem to have the privilege of selecting their hours over others. Some redundant mask policies (but these could be applicable to most related job positions in general for the past 2 years almost).

job_title: Director of Campus Recreation and Wellness in Nashville, TN
pros: Healthy work environment and a great place to start a career.
cons: Some spaces do not allow for ladder growth and pay is low for position titles and location.

job_title: Director of Student Involvement in Nashville, TN
pros: You won't find a better community of people to work with. I miss my coworkers from my Lipscomb days. Work/Life balance were always respected at my level of work. Great vacation and holiday time, and the fact that you can include 5 days as a mission trip leader is something you won't find anywhere else.
cons: Advancing from the inside is hard to do. For some reason, colleges really like to hire people from other colleges and Lipscomb is no different. You also just won't make a lot of money unless you have "Vice President" in your title.

pros: Interacting with several professor, Networking and Experience
cons: If you want to do more you are not allowed

review_title: Beware: gender pay gap is huge here
pros: The community is pleasant and supportive. Professional development is encouraged and often paid for by department heads. Flexible work from home schedule was allowed during the pandemic.
cons: The gender pay gap is significant at this institution. Salaries are notoriously low for female employees doing the same job as their male counterparts. They say they care about diversity & inclusion but few concrete steps have been taken.

pros:

job_title: Director of Admissions in Nashville, TN
pros: Time off accruals, holidays, & good people to work alongside.
cons: Salary trade off, few remote options, parking on campus

pros: The institution values flexibility in scheduling and trying to work with employees to allow them freedom to manage their life obligations outside of work - though this degrades quickly the higher up the chain one moves.
cons: The sitting president has destroyed a once well-thought-of institution. The values of the institution have been adulterated in the name of profit and ego-centered narcissism. While he is currently making his exit from the university, it will take years to correct the damage he has done, and to rebuild a healthy culture from the poisonous cesspool that has been so manipulatively and selfishly created. Any employee that reaches a managerial level will be expected to drop anything and everything and rush to the aid of the institution at literally any moment. Gone are vacations or weekends or children's birthdays or anniversaries or even church services (odd that a university that purports to be faith-based demands their employees leave worship to manage the fires created by the upper administration). Development of employees is non-existent. The environment is very transactional, and employees are helped to "transition" into new roles extremely frequently. The sitting president has adopted a practice of bringing in an executive coach whenever he has determined he no longer likes a certain employee. He will set this up as though he is interested in helping the employee develop as a leader, but in actuality it is an opportunity to positions he employee to be pushed out the door. The president does not have enough gumption and intestinal fortitude to actually stand up and fire someone, so he sets the stage where he can force one of his lower-level administrators to offer two options to the employee: 1.) direct termination, or 2.) a slap-in-the-face package of a few months of salary if the employee will submit their resignation and leave quietly (a forced resignation). It is extremely unethical and cowardly, and has become common practice that no one is immune to. The idea is that the president wants to be known as a loving and caring philanthropist, which could not possibly be further from the truth, and this puts the employee in a place where they are less likely to tell his evil tales, and more likely to say "yes, he at least gave me 3 months pay". It's sickening and cowardly. There are plenty of sycophants that surround this president, and have been aiding in building this toxic culture for years. Until a new president or board of directors comes in and cleans house, gets rid of the good-ol-boys club that is so prevalent, and begins holding the organization (including the individual employee) accountable, the institution will continue to degrade and deteriorate. On top of the numerous people who have been unethically forced out in the past year, there has been a mass exit of others who are simply tired of dealing with this administration and the absurdity that is life at Lipscomb University. It is incredibly unfortunate, because the institution has the potential to do so much good in the lives of its students, its employees, and the local community. However, the institution is currently only here to serve one person, and that is the president. For years, there has been a narrative that is very explicitly expressed that the institution is in a budget crisis. That could not be further from the truth. The institution is in a management crisis, and it would have been wise for those who had the power to do so to remove the sitting president years ago when the truth of his antics were coming to light. When public financial forms reveal an increasing salary for the president that now tops out at over $700K, but he stands before the employee base and tells them for yet another year in a row that due to budget constraints no one will be receiving a pay raise...well, that should speak for itself. Whomever takes on the presidency in the next administration will have such hard work ahead of them to rebuild the trust that has been destroyed by the current president's egomaniacal, sociopathic, narcissistic ways. I would not recommend working at Lipscomb to anyone until the currently sitting president is well on his way to others things, and has sufficiently removed himself from he daily operations of Lipscomb University.

job_title: Director of Development and Outreach in Nashville, TN
pros: Awesome university with a strong ethos.
cons: Growing pains of an excellent university.

review_title: Great work environment with strong Presidential leadership.
pros:
Lipscomb is a faith-based institution that provides a warm, supportive environment for those who profess Christianity. 
The University is very active in the community. Students, faculty, and staff are all involved in regular community service projects. A large percentage of students go on service missions at spring break.
The school is growing at a very fast pace. There are more students now than there have ever been. New and better faculty members are being hired constantly.
While it's not yet a research institution, it has become much more academically rigorous in the past few years, and it will continue to do so.
cons:
Pay is mediocre compared to similar institutions.
Some departments are understaffed. The institution prides itself on being efficient but sometimes sacrifices the effectiveness that more employees would provide.

review_title: Not too bad, but some changes to management style should be made.
pros: Most coworkers are good caring people and are willing to bend over backward to assist you if you have a problem.
cons:
Employees fear termination if they voice honest opinion if it differs from the party line.

Upper management refuses to take advice from the people who actually work in their areas of expertise (and areas that management is not expert in).

Extremely high levels of micromanagement from upper management team, specifically president's office.

review_title: Great place to work, great co-workers, but limited earning potential.
pros: The campus atmosphere is fairly informal and friendly, with lots of interaction with students and co-workers across campus. Leadership seems pretty progressive, with lots of growth plans and opportunities to expand an exisiting program, given the right circumstances. With a master's degree, the ability to adjunct is a positive towards supplementing a salary on the low-end of area average. Time off is generous, education benefits are good, and spouse/child discounts at campus school and university are higher than average.
cons: Financially, my experience has been challenging, with little ability to grow a salary or be rewarded for expanded work responsibilities and education as a staff member. Leadership can be distant and hierarchical, and most decisions at the mid to lower levels get "committeed" to death.

pros: I like the people around me as personal friends but other than that I would never recommend anyone to take a job at Lipscomb unless I didn't like them!
cons: The president is a fake, a liar, and has no integrity.  Unless you are part of Unless you are part of administration you will not be paid. We have 10 unnecessary colleges. The president seems to arbitrarily decide to make someone a dean and create a new college. They play favorites and nepotism is rampant. They have a family campaign and there bride is to offer an extra day off during spring break if enough people donate. You must give at least $20 to a certain area and then any extra you donate can be to the area of your choice. I'm not paying $520 (which is 26 pay periods multiplied by $20, the minimum amount) for an extra day off! Do they think I'm stupid?!

pros: Faculty and staff are all very warm, caring people and share a common Christian core. The campus is beautiful and includes a cafeteria, food court, post office, gym, and library - all of which are available to employees. Great location (Nashville). Tuition discounts are available for employees and their children, as well as other great benefits. Employees tend to stick around for long periods of time.
cons: Low salaries (as is common in most private higher education institutions). Many departments are short-staffed. Summers are slow for staff because students are off campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: The professors and staff in the Psychology Dept. are the absolute best in the country. This program, the dedication of the staff, the amount of student:teacher interaction and the standards that students are held to are the highest across the board. There are incredible people teaching and amazing things happening at this department. Extremely impressive research grants are coming in that highlight the confidence and respect that organizations have for the program. Words cannot express my gratitude and love for Lipscomb’s Graduate Psychology Program—now CACREP accredited as well!!! BRAVO!!!
cons: I had to graduate.

review_title: Like it..could be more diverse though
pros: Spiritual environment and really caring co-workers. They really ensure you have balance and they're really flexible when life stuff happens. I've been there for a while now and they've given many annual raises, x-mas gifts and other perks.
cons: I am a minority and I can't help but notice it's not very diverse...more so at the private grade school portion. Most all the faculty at that smaller schools are Caucasian. Some people looking from the outside could be offended. I admittedly am too.

review_title: Excellent community - A job that will make you not dread Mondays!
pros:
*Caring co-workers
*Plenty of opportunities to engage (with different ministries, opportunities, with students, etc)
*Great campus (good for walking, can use the gym and go to fitness classes)
*Good food options - the cafeteria is actually pretty delicious most days and there are lots of other fast food options 
*Always something going on. Faculty and staff are encouraged to attend chapel aka The Gathering and they have neat guest speakers from time to time. The events on campus range widely from political prayer breakfasts to the Gospel Music Awards and lots in between. I experienced a lot of great things while I was there, including some awesome theater performances
*Generous in giving time off (you get a day off for your birthday and a whole week at Christmas!)
Just a great environment for work. There are lots of great things happening there and between the mission trips and relationships being formed on campus etc lives are truly changed. 
*Good health insurance/benefits options
*Tuition breaks/reimbursement. I didn't use it, but I know it's made a big difference in some for some of my prior coworkers
cons:
I know some positions don't pay quite as much as you might expect to get in the for profit sector. Generally speaking Lipscomb makes up for it by being flexible and giving you perks elsewhere, but sometimes that is hard. The cost of living raises I was given were very small. 
Parking can be a pill, but they do offer some alternatives and if you arrive at certain times, it's not so bad.

pros:
the people were very nice

well rounded work experience. I learned about sports, events, and professional additude

hard work, Long shifts with a quick turn around . overtime was hard to get
old equipment,  Lots of the equipment was second hand
